abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Ceara Water Resources
            Management pilot Project for Brazil was satisfactory, the
            sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was high, and the Bank and borrower performance were
            both satisfactory. The lessons learned include the
            following: Integration Systems Sustainability - project
            implementation gave a general overview of a river basin
            integration system. It also gave a realistic view of the
            challenges involved in the implementation of an integration
            system, showing that financial sustainability will only be
            guaranteed by substantial urban and industrial demand,
            irrigation water demand alone being insufficient. Operations
            and Maintenance Plans - revealed the need to attach much
            more priority to the administration, operation and
            maintenance of hydraulic infrastructures. Sector Policies
            Integration - it also showed that activities carried out by
            the Secretariat for Water Resources (SRH), involving water
            resources management and the implementation of priority
            works, require similar state sector policies. Social
            Organization - it revealed the need for a permanent core
            group to organize meetings with river basin users and
            committees as a way of guaranteeing democratic access to
            information and to enrich discussions in terms of the most
            feasible alternatives for activity implementation.
            Infrastructure Management - it clearly demonstrated the need
            to renovate, maintain and properly manage existing
            infrastructure, including access to information regarding
            the condition, safety and operational strategy of existing
            systems. Planning - the project cleared demonstrated that a
            careful and participatory planning process offers a solid
            foundation and should be a requirement for the
            implementation of water resources infrastructure. Water
            Resources Management - integrated water resources management
            involves a complex set of actions focusing on structural and
            non-structural (soft) activities to balance supply and
            demand and to manage conflicts, especially in situations
            where water is scarce. Social-environmental Concerns -
            greater attention must be paid to social and environmental
            issues as a means of guaranteeing the sustainability and
            effective use of water resources systems.
